title: The man who revolutionised institutional investing

A look back at the impact of Yale's David Swensen

University endowments were once considered sleepy affairs with very small risk appetites. Investment officers typically only ventured as far as public markets, aiming to play it safe with stocks and bonds.

But over the past three decades that has all changed. You can now find endowments in every corner of finance, including esoteric strategies such as private equity, hedge funds, venture capital and even Spacs. 

In many ways, that is because of one man: David Swensen. The investment profession is mourning the loss of Yale University's endowment chief, who has died from cancer this week at the age of 67. 

Swensen, who took over the investment office of his alma mater in 1985, is a legendary figure at Yale. 

It isn't difficult to see why. He turned the New Haven-based university into one of wealthiest in the US, growing its assets from $1bn to $31bn during his 35-year tenure.  

But Swensen's influence extends far beyond the Yale campus. He is ranked alongside investing titans such as Warren Buffett, and is widely credited with reshaping how institutional investors allocate their cash.

“The really great painters are the ones that change how other people paint, like Picasso,” said Charles Ellis, the former chair of Yale's endowment. “David Swensen changed how everyone who is serious about investing thinks about investing,” 

Fresh from stints on Wall Street at Salomon Brothers and Lehman Brothers, Swensen created what has now come to be known as the “Yale model”. 

Before Swensen, dividing your cash between stocks and bonds was considered diversification while a few nascent strategies acted as a sideshow. 

Swensen turned these alternative strategies into the main act. He argued that institutions with long-term outlooks, such as universities that have been around for centuries, should put their cash in long-term investments rather than pay up for liquidity. 

It was a controversial view at the time but has since become the linchpin of institutional investing. Other university endowments quickly followed suit, many of which are now led by Swensen's protégés, and pension funds also took his lead. 

While Swensen's approach helped to drive billions of dollars of investment into private equity and hedge funds, transforming their founders into the “masters of the universe”, it wasn't always smooth sailing. 

The 2008 financial crisis tested Swensen's model, with the Yale endowment losing more than $5bn. More recently, endowments have drawn criticism as features of elite universities that already cater to society's most privileged. 

Still, Swensen was unwavering in his love for Yale and his work. “I love it! I love it!,” he said in a Lunch with the FT in 2009. “I was talking to somebody the other day who characterised endowment investing as the purest form of investing . . . I think that notion underpins why it is that I, or one of the reasons why I love my job as much as I do.”

Tata Steel gets a bold request from Sanjeev Gupta's empire

In the world of corporate finance, there's a place for chutzpah from time to time. 

But the sheer audacity that newly-public court documents reveal about the actions of V Ashok, the chief financial officer of Sanjeev Gupta's GFG Alliance, is something else. 

Here's the backdrop. In May last year, as the pandemic swept the world, Gupta's Liberty Speciality Steels missed a £12.5m payment to Tata Steel, the third in a series of instalments it owed for acquiring some of Tata's South Yorkshire steel businesses in the UK in 2017, according to Tata's court filings. (Catch up on that purchase here.) 

By July Greensill Capital, Gupta's main lender, had started making UK taxpayer-backed loans to the tycoon's loose collection of linked companies, providing a vital liquidity injection. 

In August Gupta splashed out on a £42m house in Belgravia, where he would count the Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska as a neighbour. 

But the £12.5m had still not been paid, according to the documents filed by Tata. Instead, Gupta's company had made three ad hoc £1m payments in July. 

The month of Gupta's house purchase, Ashok had a request for Kaushik De, finance director at Tata Steel Europe, which had started charging interest on the unpaid bill. 

In an email on August 18 he asked for “support and understanding” and said his company aimed to “settle all outstanding amounts” as soon as funding had been “realised”. 

Then he added: “We would also request your kind consent to waive off all interest claims on the outstanding amounts.” If it had worked, it would've been a masterstroke. 

It didn't, of course. Gupta's company made two further ad hoc payments, this time of £1.5m each, in September and October — but never paid the full balance. Over the course of the year it cited the pandemic, and later Greensill's collapse, as the reasons for the difficulties. 

So Tata is suing for the remainder, plus interest. Gupta's company owes another £10m, the fourth interim payment, this month, and Tata said in the filings, dated last month, that it would add that to the lawsuit if it was not paid. Gupta's group still has time to file a response to the legal claim. 

Catch up on the court case in this story by DD's Kaye Wiggins and the FT's Sylvia Pfeifer.  

Still, at least one company appears willing to still lend to Gupta. 

White Oak, a US-based private finance group, has agreed terms on a £200m loan for his British steelworks, Sylvia reported on Thursday. White Oak has also stepped in to refinance Gupta's Australian steel assets and associated mines. Read up here. 

From rhetoric to reality: CEOs' promises on racial justice wear thin 

The murder of George Floyd, a black man killed by a white police officer in May last year, sparked rallying cries worldwide in the name of racial justice.

Among the voices rising in condemnation of police brutality were those of corporate America, as chief executives from Apple's Tim Cook to David Solomon of Goldman Sachs declared the need for business leaders to speak up.

But as the words “systemic racism” were uttered on earnings calls for the first time, and executives moulded their vocabularies to meet the moment, did it translate into action?

As the FT's Andrew Edgecliffe-Johnson and Taylor Nicole Rogers investigated, the numbers are less evocative of the activist rhetoric expressed over the summer.

American companies have pledged to spend $50bn on racial equity since Floyd's murder, according to a tally of public promises compiled by Creative Investment Research. Yet only about $250m has actually been spent or committed to a specific cause thus far, the group found.

Job moves

  • Carlos Brito, who transformed a Brazilian regional brewer into the world's largest beer maker Anheuser-Busch InBev, is to step down as chief executive after 15 years. Confirming a FT report from last year, AB InBev named Michel Doukeris, president of the group's North America business, as Brito's replacement from July 1.

  • Jeff Blackburn, a former top business development executive at Amazon, has left a new role as partner at Bessemer Venture Partners to pursue operational positions, months after joining the firm. Bessemer said it supported his decision, and he would become an adviser and “special limited partner”.

Smart reads

Fancy offices Real estate developer Rob Speyer has done more than $11bn in deals over the past year. He has also spent lots of time talking to venture capital firms and concluded that office buildings will need to become cooler if employees are to come back. (FT)

India's retail revolution Anil Kumar Bhadra sells a modest $300 a day worth of goods at his shop in Navi Mumbai. But he has managed to capture the attention of large retailers such as Amazon.com, who want to replace his existing wholesalers as they vie to bring tens of millions of small mom-and-pop stores into their supply chains. (Nikkei Asia via FT)

Biden's blow to Big Pharma Patents are the lifeblood of the pharmaceuticals industry. So it's no surprise that Joe Biden's decision to support a temporary waiver of Covid-19 vaccine patents has prompted outrage in the sector, even as countries such as India tackle devastating waves of the virus. (FT)
